text: Hi everyone, welcome to AnimationHub.
Today we're going to break down this
comic style ink material and show the
components around creating this look.
Let's get to it. In a previous video, we
created a simple outline material which
leveraged the camera vector and pixel
normal um to derive where the edge of a
mesh is. Take that value and then with a
little more math, we can take the
results of that and force the values
closer to black and white. In another
video, we explored using different
vectors from the sky atmosphere light
direction node and the camera vector
world space node um and blending between
the two using a linear interpolation
node. In this video, we combine those
techniques and add in the use of a 2D
texture node to apply a line texture
across the surface as well as a
cross-hatching second set of lines. To
create the lines, we're using a
repeating gray line texture map. The
same texture will be used in both the
hatching and the cross-hatching sections
of the material. We use the texture
coordinate node to set the UV scale and
rotational values. Taking the result
from the R channel on the texture 2D
node, we can use a power and multiply
nodes to overdrive the result to get
brighter and darker values. The result
of this part of the graph is then
multiplied with the outline portion of
the graph.
This entire graph is then repeated again
below. Keeping in mind that the variable
names have to be changed from the first
graph parameter names. The result from
this cross-hatching graph is then
blended with the upper section using a
blend darken node. From there, we pass
the overall result through another set
of power and multiply nodes to have
additional overall control. And that's
it. See you next time.
